itemDescription: English cleric in Yorkshire and Manchester

wikipedia_page.main: James Bardsley  (1805–1886) was an English cleric of evangelical views.

response: * James Bardsley, English cleric and honorary canon of Manchester Cathedral (1805–1886)

He was the son of Canon James Bardsley, once a Bradford curate. As a boy he lived in Church Street, Burnley, attending Burnley Grammar School between 1843-48. He continued his education at Manchester Grammar School"Who was Who" 1897–1990 London, A & C Black, 1991  and Trinity College, Dublin.
* James Bardsley (priest), English cleric of evangelical views

A figure connecting Bierley and Haworth was James Bardsley. Patrick Brontë hoped in 1833 to have him as curate, but the permission of Edward Venables-Vernon-Harcourt, the Archbishop of York, was refused. He became curate at the Bierley chapel.

In 1857, McKerrow stood in for Cobden, who was ill, to lead the unsuccessful election campaigns of Bright and Milner Gibson, both of whom were radicals and pacifists. His lectures in 1861 for the Liberation Society, which campaigned for dis-establishment of the Church of England, led to a row with James Bardsley of the Manchester Church Defence Association and in the early years of the same decade he was involved with local relief efforts necessitated by the cotton famine.
